div.p: RELATION is a required attribute attached to MEMBER within BIOGRAPHY FAMILY . It specifies how the family member discussed within the Member element is related to the subject of the entry. You must therefore choose an attribute value from a list containing the following relations: Mother, Father, Sister, Brother, Aunt, Uncle, Grandfather, Grandmother, Granddaughter, Grandson, Nephew, Stepsister, Stepbrother, Stepfather, Stepmother, Cousin, Forebear, Other, Son, Daughter, Stepson, Stepdaughter, Guardian, Niece, Husband, Wife, Child, Partner.

div.codeblock: LF's paternal grandfather,Colonel Peter Hawker, was the author of Instructions to Young Sportsmen.

div.p: When the precise relationship is not indicated in a value (e.g. father-in-law or great uncle on her mother's side) you may use the value Other, OR use a near-equivalent value (Uncle for a Great-uncle). In either of these cases, try to explain the relation in your prose.
Use Partner for instances where the person is an equivalent to spouse.

Use Child when you are discussing a specific child but do not know its gender. Otherwise, use Son or Daughter. This attribute value has sometimes been used to cover several individuals, female and male, but this is incorrect: material on several people ought to be in a CHILDREN tag, not MEMBER.
Question: How should I tag Charlotte Smith's father-in-law, who had a significant impact on her life?
Answer: Use a member attribute and specify the relation as Other, mentioning that he was her father-in-law in the prose.
